Label: Lead Time
Description: The time taken for a change to flow from version control to the live systems.

Label: Deployment Frequency
Description: The frequency of deployments to the live systems.

Label: Mean Time To Recovery
Description: Often just MTTR. The mean time taken for service to be restored in the live systems fter an incident or outage.

Label: Change Failure percentage
Description: The % of changes to live systems that fail.

Label: Code under version control
Description: The % of source code that is stored in version control as the source of truth.

Label: Config under version control
Description: The % of configuration that is stored in version control as the source of truth. Source: Continuous Delivery, 2010

Label: Schemas under version control
Description: The % of schemas (for databases and other data stores) that is stored in version control as the source of truth. Source: Continuous Delivery, 2010

Label: Test data generated from version control
Description: The % of test date that is generated from scripts stored in version control as the source of truth. Source: Continuous Delivery, 2010

Label: ML models under version control
Description: The % of Machine Learning (ML) models that are generated from scripts and code stored in version control as the source of truth. Source: Continuous Delivery, 2010

Label: CodeScene Code Health
Description: Aggregate Code Health score from CodeScene. 10 is good and 1 is bad.

Label: CodeScene temporal coupling
Description: Highest temporal coupling detected - the % of time when two files change together.

Label: CodeScene Complexity
Description: The ratio of Cyclomatic Complexity to Lines of Code (LoC)

Label: CodeScene Team Autonomy
Description: TBC

Label: Tech quality
Description: How healthy is the code base?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Psychological Safety
Description: How good is the psychological safety in the team? Use the Psychological Safety Tool Kit to assess.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Speed of environment rebuild
Description: How quickly can you rebuild a typical environment?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Frequency of environment rebuild
Description: How often do you rebuild a typical environment?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Typical WIP
Description: The typical number of Work in Progress items for the team. Lower is usually better; higher WIP than team members implies blocking.
Measure: Contextual: typically, any WIP greater than the number of team members is bad. The greater that number, the worse the problem.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Flow Efficiency
Description: The Flow Efficiency for your team.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Onboarding Speed
Description: The time taken for a new team member to deploy to the live systems + the time taken for a new team member to diagnose a typical problem in the live systems.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Branch Age
Description: The typical age of non-main branches in version control. 2 days or less is healthy. Older than 2 days is increasingly unhealthy.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Steps to create a Release Candidate
Description: The number of special manual steps or clicks needed to create a Release Candidate in software. Fewer steps is better (ideally 0).
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Config Options
Description: How quickly can you diff the config for two environments?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Broken Builds
Description: How many time per month do you check in (or merge) on a broken build?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Stubs
Description: What percentage of "external" services are  only ever called directly (never stubbed)?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Spend on operability
Description: Low: no spend or no tracking   Higher score: 20-30% OR Error Budget. Upt around 30%, higher is better.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Show active feature toggles
Description: How quickly can you show all active feature toggles?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: System Health
Description: How quickly can you determine the health of the system?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Testing logging
Description: How many tests do you have in place to test that logging is working in the live systems (that log events are emitted correctly based on system activity)?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Track TLS cert expiry
Description: How quickly can you discover the expiry dates of all the TLS certs in your production env? Example: `$ echo | openssl s_client -servername {SERVER_NAME} -connect {SERVER_NAME}:{PORT} | openssl x509 -noout -dates`.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Failure Modes
Description: For non-trivial systems we expect 30-150 failure modes. Higher is generally better, because a higher number of failure modes identified means that the team has engaged with the realities of distributed computing.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Unit Test coverage
Description: Low: 10%   Higher: 80%+ coverage.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Feature Test coverage
Description: Low: 50%   Higher: 100% coverage.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Test Data
Description: Low: 20% or less of test data is generated by scripts   Higher: 100%.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: CDCs/Pact
Description: How many dependencies use 'latest'? How out of date are pinned deps?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Service Availability
Description: Low score for "100%" - higher scores for 99.5, etc. at a service level (not blanket)
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Synthetics
Description: What % of time do the synthetics detect problems before users? Higher is better.
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Service Health
Description: How often is a single, clear metric representing Service Health refreshed from live data?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: SLIs
Description: How often is a combination of metrics representing SLIs refreshed from live data?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Error Budget  / Operability
Description: How much error budget do you have left each month?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Toil
Description: Low score: toil is > 50% OR we do not deal with live services
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Time to Diagnose
Description: How long does it typically take to diagnose problems in the live/production environment? This is the time taken to understand and pinpoint what is wrong (not to fix or remediate the problem).
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Accessibility of on-call
Description: How accessible is on-call? Specifically, what proportion of your team members are actually on-call regularly?
Source: Source: Multi-team Software Delivery Assessment from Confux http://softwaredeliveryassessment.com/

Label: Team API
Description: How up-to-date is your Team API details? How many weeks since the last update?

Label: Blocking dependencies
Description: How many blocking dependencies do you suffer in a typical week/period?

Label: Team-sized services
Description: What % of the services/apps your team works on do you understand?

Label: Canary
Description: How many services (%) have a blue-green or phased roll-out capability?

Label: Blue-Green or phased
Description: How many services (%) have a canary capability?

Label: Impact Isolation
Description: When an external service fails, how often does your service fail (% of cases)?

Label: Circuit Breaker
Description: What % of your services use circuit-breaker when connecting to other systems?

Label: Exponential Back-off
Description: What % of your services use exponential back-off when connecting to other systems?

Label: Chaos Engineering
Description: What % of your services are resilient to  random single-node failures?

Label: Distributed Tracing
Description: What % of calls have full end-to-end traces?

Label: Blameless Postmortem
Description: In what % of incidents is a single root cause sought?

Label: Perception of reliability
Description: How many (%) of your user journeys explicitly manage the perception of performance or reliability?

Label: Playbooks
Description: How often (%) do your Playbooks help with human-directed triage and remeditation?

Label: UX under error conditions
Description: How many (%) of your user journeys have a defined UX under error conditions? How many (%) of your user journeys have a workaround under error conditions? Take the average of these two measures.

Label: Code-level hygiene
Description: The quality of the code and practices around code and version control

Label: Observability
Description: The ability to observe the state and behavior of the system.

Label: Decoupling and Isolation
Description: The degree to which different parts of the system are decoupled and isolated.

Label: Speed of remediation
Description: How quickly problems in the live systems can be addressed.

Label: Understanding of system behaviour
Description: The overall understanding and awareness of the software systems.

Label: Decision-making context
Description: The quality of the context in teams and individuals for making decisions about the software systems.

Label: Incentives for reliability
Description: The social drivers for improving reliability.

Label: Reliability Through Customer Eyes
Description: The reliability of the systems as seen through the eyes of the customers of the systems.

Label: Technical foundations
Description: Largely technical or technology-derived measures

Label: Socio-technical constraints
Description: Largely socio-technical derived measures

Label: Human factors
Description: Largely human-derived measures
